Subjective: Right-sided low back pain for 1.5 weeks, progressively worsening. Pain radiates down posterior and lateral right thigh/lower leg to the foot. Associated tingling and dull sensation on the outside of the right lower leg. Constant pain, all day. Impact: Unable to sleep for nights; stopped working at supermarket (job involves heavy lifting). Meds: Paracetamol and Ibuprofen (max doses) provide no relief. Pertinent Negatives: Subjectively feels strength is normal. No loss of bowel or bladder control. Normal sensation in 'riding breeches area'. ICE: Wants to get rid of the pain; concerned about needing surgery like a neighbor; asks about CT/MRI scans.
Objective: General: Appears in pain when moving onto the examination bench. Back: No visible abnormalities. No vertebral tenderness on palpation. Musculoskeletal: Positive straight leg raise on the right (pain reproduction). Negative straight leg raise on the left. Neurological: Sensation: Decreased/dull sensation on the right leg/foot compared to the left. Strength: 5/5 and symmetrical in bilateral lower extremities despite pain. Reflexes: Normal and symmetrical.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, secondary to suspected herniated nucleus pulposus (hernia). No red flags for cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Explanation: Discussed diagnosis of hernia, nerve compression, and typical course. Explained conservative management approach. 2. Medication: Start Pregabalin for nerve pain, with slow dose titration. 3. Advice: Refer to physiotherapy for exercises. No driving for 1 week after starting or changing Pregabalin dose. 4. Safety Netting: Contact immediately for worsening symptoms, specifically loss of sensation in saddle area, loss of bowel/bladder control, or significant leg weakness. 5. Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to review pain and medication.
